EN.docPage:
Upload a project

CINeMA requires a .csv file with the study outcome data and study-level risk of bias (RoB) judgements which you can upload in MyProjects. We describe below how the data should be formatted.

Binary data

If your outcome is binary, there are two possible formats that you can upload your data. The first is a long format, where each treatment arm occupies one row.

Example binary format 1:

id t r n rob
1 A 5 12 2 id specifies the study and has to be numeric
1 B 7 15 2 t specifies the treatment code and it can be either numeric or string
2 A 6 9 3 r is the number of events
2 B 7 10 3 n is the sample size
2 C 2 8 3 rob specifies risk of bias. It can take either 1, 2 and 3 or L, U, H values for low, unclear and high risk of bias

In the second format, each row represents a comparison. The number of rows that each study occupies equals the number of comparisons that it examines. Two arm studies (studies with two treatment arms) occupy one row, three arm studies occupy three rows, four arm studies occupy six rows etc.

Example binary format 2:

id t1 r1 n1 t2 r2 n2 rob
1 A 5 12 B 7 15 2 id specifies the study and has to be numeric
2 A 6 9 B 7 10 3 t1, t2 specifies the treatment codes and it can be either numeric or string
2 A 6 9 C 2 8 3 r1, r2 number of events in treatments t1 and t2
2 B 7 10 C 2 8 3 n1, n2 sample size in treatments t1 and t2
rob specifies risk of bias. It can take either 1, 2 and 3 or L, U, H values for low, unclear and high risk of bias

Continuous data

If your outcome is continuous, there are two possible formats that you can upload your data. The first is a long format, where each treatment arm occupies one row.

Example continuous format 1:

id t y sd n rob
1 A 5 5 12 2 id specifies the study and has to be numeric
1 B 7 6 15 2 t specifies the treatment code and it can be either numeric or string
2 A 6 7 9 3 y is the mean
2 B 7 8 10 3 sd is the standard deviation
2 C 2 9 8 3 n is the sample size
rob specifies risk of bias. It can take either 1, 2 and 3 or L, U, H values for low, unclear and high risk of bias

In the second format, each row represents a comparison. The number of rows that each study occupies equals the number of comparisons that it examines. Two arm studies (studies with two treatment arms) occupy one row, three arm studies occupy three rows, four arm studies occupy six rows etc.

Continuous format 2:

id t1 y1 sd1 n1 t2 y2 sd2 n2 rob
1 A 5 5 12 B 7 6 15 2 id specifies the study and has to be numeric
2 A 6 7 9 B 7 8 10 3 t1, t2 specifies the treatment codes and it can be either numeric or string
2 A 6 7 9 C 2 9 8 3 y1, y2 mean in treatments t1 and t2
2 B 7 8 10 C 2 9 8 3 sd1, sd2 standard deviations in treatments t1 and t2
rob specifies risk of bias. It can take either 1, 2 and 3 or L, U, H values for low, unclear and high risk of bias

Inverse variance data

It might be that there are not available summary data for each intervention group for each study. In such a case, an overall estimate of the effect and its standard error are collected. We provide below the required format for this kind of data, which we call ‘inverse variance data’.

Example inverse variance data format:

id t1 t2 effect se rob
1 A B 0.5 0.3 2 id specifies the study and has to be numeric
2 B D 0.8 0.2 1 t1, t2 specifies the treatment codes and it can be either numeric or string
3 A 6 0.7 0.4 3 effect The effect estimate of t1 versus t2. It can be log odds ratio, log risk ratio, log hazard ratio, mean difference or standardized mean difference. In case that this format is used, you will be asked whether your data measure a binary, continuous or time to event outcome.
se the standard error of the effect estimate
rob specifies risk of bias. It can take either 1, 2 and 3 or L, U, H values for low, unclear and high risk of bias

Notes for all data formats

  1. Although one can place any treatment names on t, we encourage users not to put string names with blanks or special characters. It is also preferable for names to be short, e.g. characters.

  2. Currently, the only allowed variable names are as described above.

  3. You can have any other variables in the dataset you wish.

  4. You can find template .csv data in xx.

General information

After uploading a dataset, you can go to general information where some NMA output is produced.

Network plot

The network plot is automatically drawn with equally sized nodes and edges. You can choose to weight nodes and/or edges according to the sample size or the number of studies. Nodes can be either be all blue or colored according to the involved studies with low (green), unclear (yellow) and high (red) risk of bias. Edges can be all black, colored according to the average risk of bias of the included studies (Mean ROB), colored according to the most prevalent bias level within each comparison (Majority NMA) or colored according to the maximum bias level within each comparison (Maximum ROB). The network plot image can be exported as .png file using the ‘Save Plot’ button.

The outcome data also appear next to the network plot. By clicking to a specific edge or node, the respective outcome data corresponding to the particular edge or node appear on the right.

Contribution Matrix

The contribution matrix provides estimations how much each direct piece of evidence contribute to each network estimate. Here you can choose:

  1. Whether you will use a fixed effect or a random effects model.

  2. The effect measure to be used.

  3. The intervention comparisons to appear. Selecting all interventions, the contributions of each pairwise to each network estimate will be calculated. For convenience, in particular in large networks, you may choose to display less than all network comparisons (rows in the contribution matrix). If this is the case, select the interventions you are interested about and specify whether you want to display all the comparisons that contain this interventions (Containing) or only the comparisons that are formed between the selected interventions (Between).

Press ‘Cancel’ if you wish to interrupt the calculations. When ready, you can download the contribution matrix (Download .csv).

Note: the choices in this step are of particular importance because they will be kept throughout the evaluation process. Only network comparisons you have chosen here will appear in the next tabs.

Pairwise meta-analysis information

A box appears for each observed treatment comparison with information on the number of studies, number of treatments and sample size per comparison. You can also see which is the mean, majority and maximum risk of bias in each treatment comparison. Pick a selection rule for judging the risk of bias of each pairwise comparison (Majority, Mean, Maximum). Then, you can edit each one of the pairwise comparisons to change the judgement upon their risk of bias. Press Save when the judgements on the direct comparisons’ risk of bias are ready.

Study Limitations

Contribution Bar Chart

When the required information in the ‘General Information’ has been filled in, a bar graph will be drawn under ‘Study Limiations’. The bars are colored according to the bias level and their length is proportional to the percentage contribution of each direct comparison to the network estimates. You can download this figure with the as .png file using the ‘Save Chart Image’ button.

NMA evaluation

Under ‘NMA evaluation’ there is one box for each network comparison. You can pick a selection rule for evaluating each network estimate with respect to Study Limitations according to the risk of bias of pairwise comparisons feeding into each estimation (Majority, Mean, Maximum).

Indirectness

To be added

Inconsistency

To be added

Imprecision

To be added

Publication Bias

To be added

Report

After assessing all five domains, you can go the ‘Report’ tab. Each row shows a network meta-analysis treatment effect along with the judgements you have made for each of the domains. You can choose to not downgrade, downgrade for one level or downgrade for two levels the evidence coming from each one of the network meta-analysis treatment effects using the selector on the right of each row. When ready, the report of evaluating evidence can be downloaded under ‘Download report’.

FAQ

Why do I get an error regarding rob values?

Check that the values are recorded either as 1, 2, 3 or L, U, H. Check that rob values are study level; that is, there are no different rob values within a study (this applied to long format data).

What if I have missing values in my data?

CINeMA does not handle datasets with missing data. You have to upload a file with complete data (or do any imputation you wish and then upload the dataset as if it was a complete).

Can I save my project to work on it later?

Yes, your projects will appear under MyProjects.
EN.aboutPage: Systematic reviews that collate data about the relative effects of multiple interventions via network meta-analysis are highly informative for decision-making purposes. A network meta-analysis provides two types of findings for a specific outcome: the relative treatment effect for all pairwise comparisons, and a ranking of the treatments. It is important to consider the confidence with which these two types of results can enable clinicians, policy makers and patients to make informed decisions. We propose an approach to determining confidence in the output of a network meta-analysis. Our proposed approach is based on methodology developed by the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) Working Group for pairwise meta-analyses. The suggested framework for evaluating a network meta-analysis acknowledges (i) the key role of indirect comparisons (ii) the contributions of each piece of direct evidence to the network meta-analysis estimates of effect size; (iii) the importance of the transitivity assumption to the validity of network meta-analysis; and (iv) the possibility of disagreement between direct evidence and indirect evidence. We apply our proposed strategy to a systematic review comparing topical antibiotics without steroids for chronically discharging ears with underlying eardrum perforations. The proposed framework can be used to determine confidence in the results from a network meta-analysis. Judgements about evidence from a network meta-analysis can be different from those made about evidence from pairwise meta-analyses.
EN.welcomePage:
Welcome to CINeMA!

CINeMA (Confidence in Network Meta-Analysis) is a web application that simplifies the evaluation of confidence in the findings from network meta-analysis.

It is based on a framework described in (1) which considers the five GRADE domains: study limitations, indirectness, inconsistency, imprecision and publication bias. The framework combines judgments about direct evidence with their statistical contribution to network meta-analysis results, enabling evaluation of the credibility of NMA treatment effects.

1. Salanti G, Del Giovane C, Chaimani A, Caldwell DM, Higgins JPT. Evaluating the quality of evidence from a network meta-analysis. PloS One. 2014;9(7):e99682.

To browse you projects or upload a new one go to My Projects
